Summary: The proposal aims to improve the sample efficiency of reinforcement learning (RL) by introducing adaptive model-based priors. It hypothesizes that a learned gating mechanism can dynamically adjust the reliance on model-based updates, combining the sample efficiency of model-based RL with the asymptotic performance of model-free methods. The proposed method includes adaptive model-value integration, uncertainty-aware model learning, and efficient prior injection. The experiment plan covers validation on toy domains, high-dimensional tasks, robustness tests, and real-world feasibility.
Strengths: Innovative approach with adaptive gating mechanism.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering various domains and scenarios.
Integration of uncertainty quantification and domain-specific priors.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on computational overhead of the gating network.
Scalability of uncertainty quantification method not thoroughly addressed.
Limited discussion on how results will be analyzed beyond performance metrics.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of the gating network be managed, especially in high-dimensional environments?
What specific metrics will be used to evaluate the robustness of the gating mechanism to model misspecification?
How will the proposed method handle cases where the model uncertainty is high across most states and actions?
Limitations: Potential computational overhead from the gating network.
Scalability of uncertainty quantification in very high-dimensional spaces.
Dependence on the quality of domain-specific priors for efficient prior injection.
